standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: $70$ and $30$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{70} \times \blueD{30} = (\greenD7 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD3 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{70} \times \blueD{30} = \greenD7 \times \blueD{3} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $7$ and $3$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD7\times \blueD3) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 21&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $21 \times 100 = 2{,}100$
$20$ and $30$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{30} = (\greenD2 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD3 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{30} = \greenD2 \times \blueD{3} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $2$ and $3$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD2\times \blueD3) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 6&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $6 \times 100 = 600$
$20$ and $60$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{60} = (\greenD2 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD6 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{60} = \greenD2 \times \blueD{6} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $2$ and $6$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD2\times \blueD6) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 12&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $12 \times 100 = 1{,}200$
$60$ and $50$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{60} \times \blueD{50} = (\greenD6 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD5 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{60} \times \blueD{50} = \greenD6 \times \blueD{5} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $6$ and $5$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD6\times \blueD5) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 30&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $30 \times 100 = 3{,}000$
$20$ and $20$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{20} = (\greenD2 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD2 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{20} \times \blueD{20} = \greenD2 \times \blueD{2} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $2$ and $2$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD2\times \blueD2) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 4&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $4 \times 100 = 400$
$90$ and $40$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{90} \times \blueD{40} = (\greenD9 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD4 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{90} \times \blueD{40} = \greenD9 \times \blueD{4} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$
Multiply $9$ and $4$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} (\greenD9\times \blueD4) &\times (\greenD{10}  \times \blueD{10})\\\\ 36&\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $36 \times 100 = 3{,}600$
$30$ and $50$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\greenD{30} \times \blueD{50} = (\greenD3 \times \greenD{10}) \times (\blueD5 \times \blueD{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\greenD{30} \times \blueD{50} = \greenD3 \times \blueD{5} \times \greenD{10} \times \blueD{10}$

Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $15 \times 100 = 1{,}500$

Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $28 \times 100 = 2{,}800$

$90$ and $50$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\maroonE{90} \times \blueE{50} = (\maroonE{9} \times \maroonE{10}) \times (\blueE{5} \times \blueE{10})$
We can change the order of the factors to make it easier to multiply:  $\maroonE{90} \times \blueE{50} = \maroonE{9} \times \blueE{5} \times \maroonE{10} \times \blueE{10}$
Multiply $9$ and $5$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} &(\maroonE{9}\times \blueE{5}) \times (\maroonE{10}  \times \blueE{10})\\\\ =&45\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $45 \times 100 = 4{,}500$
$80$ and $20$ are both multiples of $10$. Let's break them apart:  $\maroonE{80} \times \blueE{20} = (\maroonE{8} \times \maroonE{10}) \times (\blueE{2} \times \blueE{10})$

Multiply $8$ and $2$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} &(\maroonE{8}\times \blueE{2}) \times (\maroonE{10}  \times \blueE{10})\\\\ =&16\times100 \end{align}$
Multiplying by $100$ moves every digit two place values to the left.   $16 \times 100 = 1{,}600$

Multiply $5$ and $8$.  Then multiply $10$ and $10$.  $\begin{align} &(\maroonE{5}\times \blueE{8}) \times (\maroonE{10}  \times \blueE{10})\\\\ =&40\times100 \end{align}$
